Award.AwardTitle: STARS: Science Through Astronomical Research of Stars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2009 International Year of Astronomy coincides with the dimming and brightening of a variable star that can be seen with the naked eye. The American Association of Variable Star Observers and the Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum are organizing a new citizen program called STARS (Science Through Astronomical Research) that engages 8,000 amateur astronomers and non-astronomers in measuring brightness changes in the star Epsilon Aurigae, analyzing their observational data, and developing and testing their own explanatory hypotheses. The goals of the project are to increase public understanding of science by involving citizens in active research on an accessible, yet enigmatic astronomical phenomenon, and disseminate lessons learned to other citizen science programs.

A mixed methods evaluation study is monitoring the implementation and impact of the program. The project should (1) increase the number of non-astronomers who take up astronomy as a hobby, (2) increase the number of amateur astronomers who participate in other citizen science-related astronomical activities (for example, sky surveys), and (3) increase the number of non-science oriented citizens who become more interested in science. A research study is investigating how a large-scale informal citizen science project changes public understanding of scientific inquiry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Citizen Sky Project (formerly named STARS) was established during the 2009 International Year of Astronomy.  The project focused on the rare (every 27 years) 2009 eclipse of a very bright eclipsing variable star named epsilon Aurigae. Epsilon Aurigae (eps Aur) is bright enough to be seen from the city, its eclipse has an amplitude that can be detected with the naked eye, it eclipses very rarely, it is difficult for professionals to monitor (due to limited large telescope time) and, above all, it was still something of a mystery - even  after over a century of research and speculation.  The rarity of the eclipse and real scientific questions to be answered helped to spark interest in the project; and the large amplitude and brightness of the object opened participation up to urban participants and those who did not have access to a telescope.

Citizen Sky was an interdisciplinary project which generated a website, astronomical modeling software, three workshops, data analysis software, a high-end planetarium show, a journal publication, Science Olympiad educational materials, training materials on observing, data analysis, scientific paper writing, and much more. The scientific goal of the project was to collect data to help researchers uncover what is causing the eps Aur eclipse. The educational goal was to involve the public in all aspects of a scientific project. Instead of focusing solely on data collection, the project aimed to train participants to analyze data, pose their own research questions, and write up results for a peer-reviewed journal. This had not been done before in a large scale citizen science project, and the AAVSO was in a unique position to do so thanks to its history of having an engaged membership made up of experienced citizen scientists. The goal with Citizen Sky was to put it all together in one package and make it accessible to novice amateur astronomers with the belief that participants will get a better understanding of the scientific method if they are more engaged with it at every step of the way.  These goals were reached. The AAVSO collected over 21,000 observations of eps Aur during the project dates.  A special eps Aur issue of the Journal of the AAVSO contained 22 papers submitted by project staff and participants.  Education research showed that participant's attitudes toward science were affected by the experience.

The first phase of the project was dedicated to building infrastructure and data collection. The second phase of the project was dedicated to building teams and training in data analysis. The third phase of the project was dedicated to observing the end of the eclipse and writing papers for the Journal of the AAVSO (JAAVSO). The fourth phase of the project was dedicated to developing training materials that would teach observers to use their regular digital single-lens reflex cameras to collect scientific data. At the time of the project's conclusion there was no other comprehensive tutorial or manual for DSLR observing.

The citizen sky website consisted of tools for submitting and viewing variable star data, tutorials on observing and reading light curves, online forums, and a blog maintained by the project staff. The first Citizen Sky workshop focused on data collection (visual, photoelectric, and spectra) and on the science behind epsilon Aurigae. A second workshop focused on data analysis and writing scientific papers.  All workshop attendees completed outreach activities once they returned home, and workshop videos were available to public via the Citizen Sky website.
